intro: Carex lacistoma, commonly known as the narrowleaf sedges, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Cyperaceae family. It is characterized by its grass-like appearance, with narrow, linear leaves and compact, spike-like inflorescences. The plant typically grows in moist to wet habitats such as marshes, swamps, and along stream banks. Its flowering structures consist of male and female flowers arranged in separate spikes, a common feature among sedges. Carex lacistoma plays an important ecological role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various invertebrates and birds.
